security: This document discusses sensitive meetings regarding covert actions against Cuba and reconnaissance flights. It also mentions a discussion of a letter to Khrushchev and concerns over the situation in Panama. Sharing details of these discussions could compromise ongoing covert operations and diplomatic strategies. For instance, revealing the internal debates on actions against Cuba, or the procedures for reconnaissance flights, could provide adversaries with valuable intelligence and damage U.S. foreign policy efforts.
summary: This document contains memoranda regarding a Special Group (5412) meeting on February 13, 1964, covering topics such as clandestine activities against Cuba, covert action programs for various countries, and reconnaissance flights. It also includes notes from a disarmament meeting on January 18, 1964, at the White House, discussing revisions to a proposed statement for the Geneva Conference.
summary_one_paragraph: The document consists of two memoranda: one summarizing the Special Group (5412) meeting on February 13, 1964, which addressed covert activities against Cuba, covert programs for Japan, France, Tibet, Taiwan, and China, and a dispute over reconnaissance flights by SAC U-2 aircraft; and another detailing a disarmament meeting at the White House on January 18, 1964, where revisions to a statement for the Geneva Conference were discussed, along with concerns about international inspections and nuclear-free zones. The memos reveal internal debates and policy considerations within the U.S. government regarding foreign policy and national security during this period.
title: Memoranda Regarding Special Group (5412) and Disarmament Meeting
